questions.question: In a 7-year-old child with hearing loss and intellectual disability, you notice the following external ear anomaly. What could the anomaly in this case be? Preauricular sinus, b) Preauricular tag, c) Ganglion, d) Neurodermatitis
questions.explanation: The description provided matches a preauricular tag, which is a congenital anomaly often associated with other ear and hearing issues.

questions.question: An 8-month-old child was brought to your OPD with the following finding. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given image showing a malformed small pinna appearing like tubercles is suggestive of microtia. It is frequently accompanied by hearing loss.

questions.question: A child with protruding ears is brought to the OPD by his worried parents. They opt for surgical correction of the defect due to cosmetic reasons. After what age would you proceed with the surgery?
questions.explanation: Protruding ears or bat ears can be corrected anytime after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance demands. This is due to the fact that the pinna is completely developed and achieves adult configuration by the age of 6 years. Protruding ears are caused by a large concha with poorly developed antihelix and scapha. Parts of Pinna include: Helix, Antihelix, Concha, Marrow, Antitragus, Triangular fossa, Incisura terminalis, External acoustic meatus, Tragus, and Lobule.

questions.question: A 5-year-old girl was brought to you with complaints of serous discharge from a cutaneous opening on the right side of her neck. A fistulogram confirms your diagnosis of congenital auricular fistula. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?

options.A: Abnormality of the second branchial cleft
options.B: Opens in front of the tragus
options.D: Traverses close to the facial nerve

questions.explanation: Congenital auricular fistula traverses close to the facial nerve within the substance of the parotid. It is a congenital anomaly of the 1st branchial cleft. The fistula is between the external auditory canal and neck, where the upper opening is on the floor of the external auditory canal and the lower opening is on the neck between the mandible and sternocleidomastoid.

questions.question: A professional wrestler presents to your OPD with the deformity shown below. What is the most likely cause of the same?
questions.explanation: The image shows a cauliflower ear deformity, which is likely due to auricular hematoma. Auricular hematoma is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium. If left untreated, the extravasated blood may clot and then organize, resulting in a typical deformity called cauliflower ear. It is also called pugilistic or boxer's ear. It is often seen in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players due to blunt trauma. Treatment comprises aspiration of the hematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing, to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. If aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics.

questions.question: A young man is rushed to the ER following a road traffic accident with severe injuries and a completely avulsed pinna. How would you preserve the avulsed pinna until the patient is stable enough for reconstructive surgery?

options.A: By storing it in a refrigerator in isotonic saline
options.B: By suturing it to buccal mucosa after careful cleaning
options.C: By peeling its skin and inserting cartilage into the postauricular area
options.D: By implanting it into the abdominal cavity

questions.explanation: The avulsed pinna is preserved by peeling its skin and inserting the cartilage into the postauricular area, which can be preserved for delayed reconstruction. However, immediate reimplantation using microvascular techniques would be ideal. If the pinna is still attached to the head by a small pedicle of skin, primary reattachment should be considered.

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with a painful ear swelling as shown below?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of painful, erythematous ear swelling is suggestive of perichondritis. The most common cause is trauma, either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or a furuncle of the meatus. The most common organism responsible is Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The image given below shows a patient with a cauliflower ear deformity. It is also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear. It is usually caused by repeated episodes of trauma. Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. Otitis externa, also called swimmer's ear, is the inflammation of the ear canal.

questions.question: A middle-aged man presents with a lesion as shown below. He is unable to sleep on the affected side. There is no history of trauma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A small tender nodule in the helix in a middle-aged patient is suggestive of chondrodermatitis nodularis chronica helicis. The patient will have difficulty sleeping on the affected side. Treatment includes excision of the lesion.

questions.question: A patient is planned for excision of the following lesion. Which of the following measures will not prevent its recurrence post-excision?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a keloid of the pinna and neoadjuvant chemotherapy does not reduce its recurrence post-excision. Keloid commonly occurs following trauma. The common sites are lobule and helix. There is a high chance of recurrence after excision, which can be prevented by: Intralesional steroids, pre- and post-operative radiotherapy.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about furunculosis of the ear?

options.A: Patients with repeated attacks should be investigated for diabetes mellitus
options.B: Most common cause is staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle
options.C: Can occur anywhere in the external auditory canal
options.D: Tragal sign is negative in the majority of cases

questions.explanation: Patients with repeated attacks of furunculosis should be investigated for diabetes mellitus. A furuncle is a staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle. As the hairs are confined only to the cartilaginous part of the meatus, a furuncle is seen only in the outer one-third of the EAC. Symptoms are severe compared to signs as the skin over the EAC is tightly adherent. The tragal sign is positive, and there is an obliteration of the retroauricular groove. It is treated by incision and drainage or 10% ichthammol glycerine wicks and antibiotics.

questions.question: Which of the following is synonymous with swimmer's ear?
questions.explanation: Swimmer's ear is synonymous with diffuse otitis externa. The normal pH of the external auditory canal is acidic. Any condition that makes the pH alkaline predisposes to otitis externa. This includes situations such as: • Hot & humid climate (excessive sweating) and • Prolonged swimming

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with right-sided ear discharge, itching, and pain for the past 4 days. He gives a history of insect entry into the external auditory canal, which he removed himself. On examination, there is purulent discharge in a narrow canal and the tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most effective single treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of diffuse otitis externa following a trauma. Aural toilet remains the most effective single treatment for this condition. All exudate and debris should be carefully removed, with special emphasis on the anteroinferior meatal recess, which forms a blind pocket and acts as a reservoir of infective secretion. The aural toilet can be done by dry mopping, suction clearance, or irrigating the canal with warm, sterile normal saline. Further treatment modalities: • After the aural toilet is done, wicks medicated with antibiotic-steroid preparation can be used. These wicks have to be changed daily for 2 to 3 days, which thereafter can be substituted by ear drops. • Broad-spectrum systemic antibiotics are used when there is cellulitis and acute tender lymphadenitis. • Analgesics are usually a part of management, as otitis externa is associated with severe pain. • Gauze wick soaked in 10% ichthammol glycerine is used to reduce swelling. • Astringents such as aluminum acetate (8%) or silver nitrate (3%) are used to dry up an oozing meatus.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of otomycosis?
questions.explanation: Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal that often occurs due to Aspergillus niger (most common), Aspergillus fumigatus, or Candida albicans.

questions.question: A young man presented with irritation and itching in the ear, associated with watery discharge and a musty odor. Otoscopic imaging is shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario, along with the otoscopic image showing black-headed filamentous growth, is suggestive of otomycosis by Aspergillus niger. Irritation and itching are the most predominant symptoms of Aspergillus niger infection. Pain is predominant in Aspergillus flavus infection. The fungal mass in otomycosis is likened to a wet blotting paper/wet newspaper appearance. The appearances of otomycosis on otoscopy and the causative organisms are: • Black-headed filamentous growth - Aspergillus niger infection; • Green or brown - Aspergillus fumigatus infection; • White and creamy deposit - Candida infection. Rhizopus oryzae is one of the causative agents of mucormycosis. The common clinical form of this opportunistic infection is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM). It is rarely implicated in otomycosis.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with right-sided facial weakness. On examination, she has vesicles in the external auditory canal and over the tympanic membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of facial paralysis along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus). Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy. Often, the 8th cranial nerve is also involved, which causes hearing loss and vertigo. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve. Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve. Möebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing limited ocular abduction. Melkersson syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of: facial paralysis, swelling of lips, and fissured tongue.

questions.question: A 60-year-old diabetic presents to the ER with fever, excruciating left ear pain, and otorrhea which is unresponsive to antibiotics. On examination, she has a deviation of the angle of the mouth to the right side, and granulation tissue is seen in the left external auditory canal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa. It is termed malignant, even though it is an infection, due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about malignant otitis externa?

options.A: It is due to Pseudomonas infection
options.C: Technetium 99 bone scan is used for follow-up
options.D: Facial nerve is the most common affected nerve

questions.explanation: Technetium 99 bone scan remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to follow up response to treatment. It is particularly useful when the clinical suspicion for malignant otitis externa is high but the CT scan is negative. Features of malignant otitis externa: • Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs. • Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal. • Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. • Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen. • Mitotic figures will be normal since it is an infective and not a malignant condition. • Gallium-67 is more useful in the follow-up of the patient.

questions.question: A young man presents to the OPD with complaints of intense irritation in the ear following the use of ear drops. Examination reveals vesicle formation, oozing, and crusting in the canal. Which of the following is responsible?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of eczematous otitis externa and the drug implicated is neomycin. Eczematous otitis externa is due to hypersensitivity to infective organisms or topical ear drops such as chloromycetin or neomycin, etc. The presence of intense irritation, vesicle formation, oozing, and crusting in the canal is observed. Management involves stopping the implicated ear drops, changing to a different combination and application of steroid cream. Note: Otitis externa hemorrhagica is a condition characterized by the formation of hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. This causes severe pain in the ear and blood-stained discharge when the bullae rupture. It is probably viral in origin.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about wax?

options.A: Contains secretions of glands in the external auditory canal
options.B: Formed by dried-up middle ear discharge
options.D: Is extruded out on its own during jaw movements

questions.explanation: Wax or cerumen is not made up of middle ear discharge. Composition of wax: • Secretions of ceruminous glands (modified apocrine sweat glands) • Secretions of the sebaceous gland (fatty secretion) • Desquamated epithelial cells • Hair. Wax is normally expelled by the movement of the jaw during eating, talking. Functions include antibacterial action and trapping of foreign bodies and dirt. Impacted wax causes a sensation of blockage of the ear, reduced hearing, vertigo, tinnitus. Treatment: • Softening with ceruminolytics like 2% paradichlorobenzene, 5% sodium bicarbonate in equal parts of glycerine and water. • Syringing or instrumentation or suction clearance.

questions.question: Ceruminous glands are modifications of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. Ceruminous and sebaceous glands open into the space of the hair follicle in the external auditory canal.

questions.question: While performing syringing for a patient with impacted wax, along which wall of the meatus would you direct the jet of water?
questions.explanation:
During syringing, the pinna is pulled upwards and backward and the water jet is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus. This is preferred because of two anatomical reasons: 
      • On maneuvering the pinna to bring the EAC into a straight configuration, the posterior wall is straighter and easily accessible than the anterior wall.
      • The posteroinferior wall of EAC is supplied by the vagus. Direct stimulation of this can lead to sudden cardiac arrest.
   Complications of syringing: 
      • Vertigo—caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
      • Rupture of the tympanic membrane
      • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation
   Contraindications for syringing: 
      • Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
      • Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery

questions.question: After the extraction of the mass in a patient with keratosis obturans, it is sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is seen here?
questions.explanation: Keratosis obturans is the collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus. The keratin plug is arranged in a lamellar fashion, not in a random pattern.

questions.question: Which of the following is not seen in a patient with keratosis obturans?

options.D: Narrowing of meatus causing facial nerve palsy

questions.explanation: Keratosis obturans, by pressure effect, causes absorption of bone which causes widening (not narrowing) of the meatus leading to facial nerve palsy. Normally, epithelium from the surface of the tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall. Failure of this migration, or obstruction to migration caused by wax, may lead to keratosis obturans which is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. Features of keratosis obturans: • Severe otalgia • Conductive hearing loss • Thickened tympanic membrane • Keratin plug/pearly white mass occluding the canal • Widened ear canal - may lead to facial nerve paralysis • Hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulomas. Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent isolate. Keratosis obturans may be associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.

questions.question: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called?
questions.explanation: The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty. Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of a crescent-shaped portion of conchal cartilage to widen the external auditory meatus. It is performed in combination with all-canal wall-down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for easy access to the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning. It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricles. A sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus, leading to the retention of wax and difficulty in hearing. Other options: Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing. It is ossicular reconstruction only or ossicular reconstruction with myringoplasty. Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only. Option D: Otoplasty is the correction of external ear/deformities of the pinna.

questions.question: In which of the following is meatoplasty not performed?
questions.explanation: Meatoplasty is not a part of canal wall-up (CWU) procedures as the meatus appears normal. However, meatoplasty is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures, like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meatus helps to easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning. It is also done in atresia/stenosis to recanalize the ear and in tortuous canals post-tympanoplasty to improve hearing.

questions.question: While performing otoscopy, which of the following would not indicate a normal tympanic membrane?

options.D: Mobile with a change in middle ear pressures

questions.explanation: The normal tympanic membrane is concave to the EAC with the maximum concavity at the umbo. Features of normal TM: • Pearly grey in color • Shiny • Degree of transparency varies • Mobile with change in middle ear pressures

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding a retracted tympanic membrane?

options.D: Sickling of anterior and posterior malleal folds

questions.explanation: A retracted TM is dull and lustreless, not shiny and pearly white. Features of a retracted TM: • The cone of light is absent or interrupted. • The handle of the malleus appears foreshortened. • The lateral process of the malleus becomes more prominent. • Anterior and posterior malleal folds become sickle-shaped. The image below shows a retracted TM with the above-mentioned findings.

questions.question: While performing routine otoscopy, a patient is found to have tympanic membrane retraction with the pars tensa draping over the incudostapedial joint. What is the grade of retraction?
questions.explanation: Draping of pars tensa over the incudostapedial joint is classified as Sade's grade II retraction. Sade classification of retraction of Pars tensa: Tos classification of retraction of Pars flaccida: Grade Description Grade Mild retraction not touching the long process of the incus. Grade 2 Grade 3 Retracted drum touching the long process of the incus. Touching promontory but mobile on siegelization - atelectasis of the middle ear. Grade 4 Plastered to promontory and immobile - adhesive middle ear. Grade Description Grade 1 Grade 2 Mild attic retraction not touching the neck of the malleus. Touching the neck of the malleus. Limited outer attic wall erosion. Grade 3 Severe outer attic wall erosion.
